title: ðŸ“‹ Why is CDC important for Customer Service?
intro: Knowing CDC brings direct benefits to your daily service work:

c1.title: Security
c1.text: Security in guiding the customer, knowing exactly what the law allows or not.

c2.title: Compliance
c2.text: Correct answers aligned with the law, avoiding legal problems for the company.

c3.title: Efficiency
c3.text: Reduction of rework by resolving issues correctly the first time.

c4.title: Credibility
c4.text: More professionalism, trust and credibility in service.

attention_text: Knowing the CDC does not mean memorizing all articles, but understanding the basic principles that guide consumer relations.

quiz.question: A customer claims heatedly: 'The Consumer Protection Code says I'm always right! That's why you are obliged to do what I want!'. Based on the balance proposed by the CDC, how do you interpret this statement?
quiz.opt_a: A) 'The customer is always right', and the CDC was created precisely to ensure their will prevails in any situation.
quiz.feedback_wrong_a: The CDC does not say 'the customer is always right'. It seeks BALANCE, protecting the most vulnerable part but establishing limits for everyone.
quiz.opt_b: B) The customer is mistaken. The CDC seeks to balance the relationship, protecting the weaker party (consumer), but also establishing duties and limits to avoid abuse.
quiz.opt_c: C) The customer is wrong, as the CDC is a law that serves only to punish companies that commit crimes against the popular economy.
quiz.feedback_wrong_c: The CDC is much broader than punishing crimes. It regulates the ENTIRE consumption relationship: advertising, contracts, warranties, deadlines and rights.
quiz.opt_d: D) The customer is partially right, the CDC guarantees they are right, but only if they present the original invoice.
quiz.feedback_wrong_d: The invoice is important to prove purchase, but the consumer's right does not depend only on it. CDC's balance is not conditioned on documents.
quiz.feedback: Correct Answer! The goal of the CDC is harmony and balance in consumer relations, not blind favoritism.
